quiz.title: Chemistry Grade 12: Unit 10 Quiz 5
quiz.subtitle: 10.5: Entropy
quiz.subject: Chemistry
quiz.topic: Concept of disorder, microstates, and entropy measurement

questions.question: Which of the following best defines thermodynamic entropy ($S$)?
options: A measure of the dispersal of energy and the disorder of a system.
The total heat content of a system at constant pressure.
The energy available to do useful work.
The average kinetic energy of the particles in a system.
questions.explanation: Entropy is a measure of the number of possible microstates (arrangements) available to a system; more arrangements mean higher entropy.

questions.question: Which state of matter for a given substance generally has the highest entropy?
questions.explanation: Gaseous particles have the greatest freedom of motion and the highest number of possible positions/velocities, resulting in the highest entropy.

questions.question: According to the Third Law of Thermodynamics, what is the entropy of a perfect crystal at $0\ K$?
questions.explanation: At absolute zero ($0\ K$), all molecular motion stops in a perfect crystal, meaning there is only one possible microstate, so $S = 0$.

questions.question: What are the standard units for entropy ($S$)?
questions.explanation: Entropy is measured in Joules per mole-Kelvin. Note that unlike enthalpy, it is usually expressed in Joules (J) rather than kiloJoules (kJ).

questions.question: Which of the following processes results in an increase in entropy ($\Delta S > 0$)?
questions.explanation: Sublimation involves a phase change from a highly ordered solid to a highly disordered gas, which significantly increases entropy.

questions.question: The Second Law of Thermodynamics states that for any spontaneous process:
options: The total entropy of the universe must increase.
The entropy of the system must decrease.
The enthalpy of the universe must remain constant.
The temperature of the system must increase.
questions.explanation: While the entropy of a system can decrease, the sum of the entropy changes of the system and the surroundings must be positive for spontaneity.

questions.question: How does increasing the temperature affect the entropy of a substance?
questions.explanation: Higher temperatures increase the kinetic energy and the range of possible velocities for particles, thereby increasing the number of microstates.

questions.question: What is the formula for calculating the standard entropy change of a reaction ($\Delta S^{\circ}_{rxn}$)?
questions.explanation: Like enthalpy, the change in entropy is a state function calculated as the sum of the absolute entropies of products minus reactants.

questions.question: Which molecule would you expect to have a higher standard entropy: $CH_{4}(g)$ or $C_{3}H_{8}(g)$?
options: They have the same entropy because both are gases.
questions.explanation: Propane ($C_{3}H_{8}$) is a larger, more complex molecule with more atoms, allowing for more vibrational and rotational modes (microstates).

questions.question: Dissolving a solid solute into a liquid solvent usually:
options: Increases the entropy of the system.
Decreases the entropy of the system.
Reduces the temperature to absolute zero.
questions.explanation: When a solid dissolves, its highly ordered crystal lattice is broken down, and the particles disperse throughout the solvent, increasing disorder.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You have a great conceptual grasp of entropy and disorder.
scoreMessages.70: Good job. You understand how state and temperature influence entropy.
scoreMessages.50: Satisfactory. Remember that gases always have higher entropy than solids.
scoreMessages.0: Focus on the definition of entropy as energy dispersal and microstates.
